member.name: T:OpenAI_API.APIAuthentication

member.summary: The Organization ID to count API requests against. This can be found at https://beta.openai.com/account/org-settings.

member.name: M:OpenAI_API.APIAuthentication.op_Implicit(System.String)~OpenAI_API.APIAuthentication
member.summary: Allows implicit casting from a string, so that a simple string API key can be provided in place of an instance of
member.param: The API key to convert into a .

member.summary: Instantiates a new Authentication object with the given , which may be .

member.name: M:OpenAI_API.APIAuthentication.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Instantiates a new Authentication object with the given , which may be . For users who belong to multiple organizations, you can specify which organization is used. Usage from these API requests will count against the specified organization's subscription quota.
member.param: The API key, required to access the API endpoint.
The Organization ID to count API requests against. This can be found at https://beta.openai.com/account/org-settings.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.APIAuthentication.Default
member.summary: The default authentication to use when no other auth is specified. This can be set manually, or automatically loaded via environment variables or a config file.

member.name: M:OpenAI_API.APIAuthentication.LoadFromEnv
member.summary: Attempts to load api key from environment variables, as "OPENAI_KEY" or "OPENAI_API_KEY". Also loads org if from "OPENAI_ORGANIZATION" if present.
member.returns: Returns the loaded any api keys were found, or if there were no matching environment vars.

member.name: M:OpenAI_API.APIAuthentication.LoadFromPath(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Attempts to load api keys from a configuration file, by default ".openai" in the current directory, optionally traversing up the directory tree
member.param: The directory to look in, or for the current directory
The filename of the config file
Whether to recursively traverse up the directory tree if the is not found in the
member.returns: Returns the loaded any api keys were found, or if it was not successful in finding a config (or if the config file didn't contain correctly formatted API keys)

member.name: M:OpenAI_API.APIAuthentication.ValidateAPIKey
member.summary: Tests the api key against the OpenAI API, to ensure it is valid. This hits the models endpoint so should not be charged for usage.
member.returns: if the api key is valid, or if empty or not accepted by the OpenAI API.

member.name: M:OpenAI_API.AuthHelpers.ThisOrDefault(OpenAI_API.APIAuthentication)
member.summary: A helper method to swap out objects with the authentication, possibly loaded from ENV or a config file.
member.param: The specific authentication to use if not
member.returns: Either the provided or the

member.name: T:OpenAI_API.ApiResultBase
member.summary: Represents a result from calling the OpenAI API, with all the common metadata returned from every endpoint

members.member: The time when the result was generated

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.ApiResultBase.CreatedUnixTime
member.summary: The time when the result was generated in unix epoch format

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.ApiResultBase.Model
member.summary: Which model was used to generate this result.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.ApiResultBase.Object
member.summary: Object type, ie: text_completion, file, fine-tune, list, etc

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.ApiResultBase.Organization
member.summary: The organization associated with the API request, as reported by the API.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.ApiResultBase.ProcessingTime
member.summary: The server-side processing time as reported by the API. This can be useful for debugging where a delay occurs.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.ApiResultBase.RequestId
member.summary: The request id of this API call, as reported in the response headers. This may be useful for troubleshooting or when contacting OpenAI support in reference to a specific request.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.ApiResultBase.OpenaiVersion
member.summary: The Openai-Version used to generate this response, as reported in the response headers. This may be useful for troubleshooting or when contacting OpenAI support in reference to a specific request.

member.name: T:OpenAI_API.Audio.AudioRequest
member.summary: Parameters for requests made by the .

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Audio.AudioRequest.Model
member.summary: The model to use for this request. Currently only is supported.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Audio.AudioRequest.Prompt
member.summary: An optional text to guide the model's style or continue a previous audio segment. The prompt should match the audio language for transcriptions, or English for translations.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Audio.AudioRequest.Language
member.summary: The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in ISO-639-1 format will improve accuracy and latency.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Audio.AudioRequest.ResponseFormat
member.summary: The format of the transcript output, should be one of the options in . See

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Audio.AudioRequest.Temperature
member.summary: The sampling temperature, between 0 and 1. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output more random, while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic. If set to 0, the model will use log probability to automatically increase the temperature until certain thresholds are hit.

member.name: T:OpenAI_API.Audio.AudioRequest.ResponseFormats
member.summary: The format of the transcript output. See

member.name: T:OpenAI_API.Audio.AudioResultVerbose
member.summary: Represents a verbose_json output from the OpenAI Transcribe or Translate endpoints.

member.name: T:OpenAI_API.Audio.ITextToSpeechEndpoint
member.summary: The Endpoint for the Text to Speech API. This allows you to generate audio from text. See

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Audio.ITextToSpeechEndpoint.DefaultTTSRequestArgs
member.summary: This allows you to set default parameters for every request, for example to set a default voice or model. For every request, if you do not have a parameter set on the request but do have it set here as a default, the request will automatically pick up the default value.

member.name: M:OpenAI_API.Audio.ITextToSpeechEndpoint.GetSpeechAsStreamAsync(OpenAI_API.Audio.TextToSpeechRequest)
member.summary: Calls the API to create speech from text, and returns the raw stream of the audio file.
member.param: The text to speech request to submit to the API
member.returns: A stream of the audio file in the requested format.

member.name: M:OpenAI_API.Audio.ITextToSpeechEndpoint.GetSpeechAsStreamAsync(System.String,System.String,System.Nullable{System.Double},System.String,OpenAI_API.Models.Model)
member.summary: Calls the API to create speech from text, and returns the raw stream of the audio file.
member.param: The text to generate audio for. The maximum length is 4096 characters.
The voice to use when generating the audio. Supported voices can be found in .
The speed of the generated audio. Select a value from 0.25 to 4.0. 1.0 is the default.
The default response format is "mp3", but other formats are available in . See
TTS is an AI model that converts text to natural sounding spoken text. OpenAI offers two different model variates, is optimized for real time text to speech use cases and is optimized for quality.
member.returns: A stream of the audio file in the requested format.

member.summary: Transcribe audio into text, with optional translation into English.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Audio.ITranscriptionEndpoint.DefaultRequestArgs
member.summary: This allows you to set default parameters for every request, for example to set a default language. For every request, if you do not have a parameter set on the request but do have it set here as a default, the request will automatically pick up the default value.

member.name: M:OpenAI_API.Audio.ITranscriptionEndpoint.GetAsFormatAsync(System.IO.Stream,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Nullable{System.Double})
member.summary: Gets the transcription of the audio stream, in the specified format
member.param: The stream containing audio data, in one of these formats: flac, mp3, mp4, mpeg, mpga, m4a, ogg, wav, or webm.
The name of the audio file in the stream. This does not have to be real, but it must contain the correct file extension. For example, "file.mp3" if you are supplying an mp3 audio stream.
The format of the response. Suggested value are or . For text and Json formats, try or instead.
The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in ISO-639-1 format will improve accuracy and latency.
An optional text to guide the model's style or continue a previous audio segment. The prompt should match the audio language.

The sampling temperature, between 0 and 1. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output more random, while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic. If set to 0, the model will use log probability to automatically increase the temperature until certain thresholds are hit.
member.returns: A string of the transcribed text

member.name: T:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatEndpoint
member.summary: ChatGPT API endpoint. Use this endpoint to send multiple messages and carry on a conversation.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatEndpoint.DefaultChatRequestArgs
member.summary: This allows you to set default parameters for every request, for example to set a default temperature or max tokens. For every request, if you do not have a parameter set on the request but do have it set here as a default, the request will automatically pick up the default value.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatEndpoint.Endpoint
member.summary: The name of the endpoint, which is the final path segment in the API URL. For example, "completions".

member.name: M:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatEndpoint.#ctor(OpenAI_API.OpenAIAPI)
member.summary: Constructor of the api endpoint. Rather than instantiating this yourself, access it through an instance of as .

member.name: M:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatEndpoint.CreateConversation(OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest)
member.summary: Creates an ongoing chat which can easily encapsulate the conversation. This is the simplest way to use the Chat endpoint.
member.param: Allows setting the parameters to use when calling the ChatGPT API. Can be useful for setting temperature, presence_penalty, and more. See OpenAI documentation for a list of possible parameters to tweak.
member.returns: A which encapsulates a back and forth chat between a user and an assistant.

member.name: M:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatEndpoint.CreateChatCompletionAsync(OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest)
member.summary: Ask the API to complete the request using the specified parameters. This is non-streaming, so it will wait until the API returns the full result. Any non-specified parameters will fall back to default values specified in if present.
member.param: The request to send to the API.
member.returns: Asynchronously returns the completion result. Look in its property for the results.

member.name: M:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatEndpoint.CreateChatCompletionAsync(OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest,System.Int32)
member.summary: Ask the API to complete the request using the specified parameters. This is non-streaming, so it will wait until the API returns the full result. Any non-specified parameters will fall back to default values specified in if present.
member.param: The request to send to the API.
Overrides as a convenience.

The model to use. See the ChatGPT models available from

What sampling temperature to use. Higher values means the model will take more risks. Try 0.9 for more creative applications, and 0 (argmax sampling) for ones with a well-defined answer. It is generally recommend to use this or but not both.

An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered. It is generally recommend to use this or but not both.
How many different choices to request for each prompt.
How many tokens to complete to. Can return fewer if a stop sequence is hit.
The scale of the penalty for how often a token is used. Should generally be between 0 and 1, although negative numbers are allowed to encourage token reuse.
The scale of the penalty applied if a token is already present at all. Should generally be between 0 and 1, although negative numbers are allowed to encourage token reuse.

Maps tokens (specified by their token ID in the tokenizer) to an associated bias value from -100 to 100. Mathematically, the bias is added to the logits generated by the model prior to sampling. The exact effect will vary per model, but values between -1 and 1 should decrease or increase likelihood of selection; values like -100 or 100 should result in a ban or exclusive selection of the relevant token.
One or more sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.

member.summary: By default, the model will use the auto setting which will look at the image input size and decide if it should use the low or high setting.

member.name: F:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatMessage.ImageInput.DetailLow
member.summary: low will disable the high res model. The model will receive a low-res 512px x 512px version of the image, and represent the image with a budget of 65 tokens. This allows the API to return faster responses and consume fewer input tokens for use cases that do not require high detail.

member.name: F:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatMessage.ImageInput.DetailHigh
member.summary: high will enable high res mode, which first allows the model to see the low res image and then creates detailed crops of input images as 512px squares based on the input image size. Each of the detailed crops uses twice the token budget (65 tokens) for a total of 129 tokens.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest.Temperature
member.summary: What sampling temperature to use. Higher values means the model will take more risks. Try 0.9 for more creative applications, and 0 (argmax sampling) for ones with a well-defined answer. It is generally recommend to use this or but not both.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest.TopP
member.summary: An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered. It is generally recommend to use this or but not both.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest.NumChoicesPerMessage
member.summary: How many different choices to request for each message. Defaults to 1.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest.Stream
member.summary: Specifies where the results should stream and be returned at one time. Do not set this yourself, use the appropriate methods on instead.

member.summary: This is only used for serializing the request into JSON, do not use it directly.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest.MultipleStopSequences
member.summary: One or more sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest.StopSequence
member.summary: The stop sequence where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence. For convenience, if you are only requesting a single stop sequence, set it here

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest.MaxTokens
member.summary: How many tokens to complete to. Can return fewer if a stop sequence is hit. Defaults to 16.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest.FrequencyPenalty
member.summary: The scale of the penalty for how often a token is used. Should generally be between 0 and 1, although negative numbers are allowed to encourage token reuse. Defaults to 0.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest.PresencePenalty
member.summary: The scale of the penalty applied if a token is already present at all. Should generally be between 0 and 1, although negative numbers are allowed to encourage token reuse. Defaults to 0.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest.LogitBias
member.summary: Modify the likelihood of specified tokens appearing in the completion. Accepts a json object that maps tokens(specified by their token ID in the tokenizer) to an associated bias value from -100 to 100. Mathematically, the bias is added to the logits generated by the model prior to sampling. The exact effect will vary per model, but values between -1 and 1 should decrease or increase likelihood of selection; values like -100 or 100 should result in a ban or exclusive selection of the relevant token.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest.user
member.summary: A unique identifier representing your end-user, which can help OpenAI to monitor and detect abuse.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest.ResponseFormat
member.summary: An object specifying the format that the model must output. Setting to enables JSON mode, which guarantees the message the model generates is valid JSON, assuming that the is not "length". Important: when using JSON mode, you must also instruct the model to produce JSON yourself via a system or user message. Without this, the model may generate an unending stream of whitespace until the generation reaches the token limit, resulting in a long-running and seemingly "stuck" request.Also note that the message content may be partially cut off if `finish_reason= "length"`, which indicates the generation exceeded `max_tokens` or the conversation exceeded the max context length.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest.ResponseFormatRaw
member.summary: This is only used for serializing the request into JSON, do not use it directly.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Chat.Conversation.AutoTruncateOnContextLengthExceeded
member.summary: Sometimes the total length of your conversation can get too long to fit in the ChatGPT context window. In this case, the event will be called, if supplied. If not supplied and this is , then the first one or more user or assistant messages will be automatically deleted from the beginning of the conversation message history until the API call succeeds. This may take some time as it may need to loop several times to clear enough messages. If this is set to false and no is supplied, then an will be raised when the API returns a context_length_exceeded error.

member.summary: This allows you to set default parameters for every request, for example to set a default temperature or max tokens. For every request, if you do not have a parameter set on the request but do have it set here as a default, the request will automatically pick up the default value.

member.name: M:OpenAI_API.Chat.IChatEndpoint.CreateConversation(OpenAI_API.Chat.ChatRequest)
member.summary: Creates an ongoing chat which can easily encapsulate the conversation. This is the simplest way to use the Chat endpoint.
member.param: Allows setting the parameters to use when calling the ChatGPT API. Can be useful for setting temperature, presence_penalty, and more. See OpenAI documentation for a list of possible parameters to tweak.
member.returns: A which encapsulates a back and forth chat between a user and an assistant.

member.summary: Ask the API to complete the request using the specified parameters. This is non-streaming, so it will wait until the API returns the full result. Any non-specified parameters will fall back to default values specified in if present.
member.param: The array of messages to send to the API
The model to use. See the ChatGPT models available from

What sampling temperature to use. Higher values means the model will take more risks. Try 0.9 for more creative applications, and 0 (argmax sampling) for ones with a well-defined answer. It is generally recommend to use this or but not both.

An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered. It is generally recommend to use this or but not both.
How many different choices to request for each prompt.
How many tokens to complete to. Can return fewer if a stop sequence is hit.
The scale of the penalty for how often a token is used. Should generally be between 0 and 1, although negative numbers are allowed to encourage token reuse.
The scale of the penalty applied if a token is already present at all. Should generally be between 0 and 1, although negative numbers are allowed to encourage token reuse.

Maps tokens (specified by their token ID in the tokenizer) to an associated bias value from -100 to 100. Mathematically, the bias is added to the logits generated by the model prior to sampling. The exact effect will vary per model, but values between -1 and 1 should decrease or increase likelihood of selection; values like -100 or 100 should result in a ban or exclusive selection of the relevant token.
One or more sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.
member.returns: Asynchronously returns the completion result. Look in its property for the results.

member.name: T:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionEndpoint
member.summary: Text generation is the core function of the API. You give the API a prompt, and it generates a completion. The way you program the API to do a task is by simply describing the task in plain english or providing a few written examples. This simple approach works for a wide range of use cases, including summarization, translation, grammar correction, question answering, chatbots, composing emails, and much more (see the prompt library for inspiration).

member.summary: Ask the API to complete the prompt(s) using the specified parameters. This is non-streaming, so it will wait until the API returns the full result. Any non-specified parameters will fall back to default values specified in if present.
member.param: The prompt to generate from
The model to use. You can use to see all of your available models, or use a standard model like .
How many tokens to complete to. Can return fewer if a stop sequence is hit.

What sampling temperature to use. Higher values means the model will take more risks. Try 0.9 for more creative applications, and 0 (argmax sampling) for ones with a well-defined answer. It is generally recommend to use this or but not both.

An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered. It is generally recommend to use this or but not both.
How many different choices to request for each prompt.
The scale of the penalty applied if a token is already present at all. Should generally be between 0 and 1, although negative numbers are allowed to encourage token reuse.
The scale of the penalty for how often a token is used. Should generally be between 0 and 1, although negative numbers are allowed to encourage token reuse.

Include the log probabilities on the logprobs most likely tokens, which can be found in -> . So for example, if logprobs is 10, the API will return a list of the 10 most likely tokens. If logprobs is supplied, the API will always return the logprob of the sampled token, so there may be up to logprobs+1 elements in the response.
Echo back the prompt in addition to the completion.
One or more sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.
member.returns: Asynchronously returns the completion result. Look in its property for the completions.

member.name: T:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest
member.summary: Represents a request to the Completions API. Mostly matches the parameters in the OpenAI docs, although some have been renamed or expanded into single/multiple properties for ease of use.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.Model
member.summary: ID of the model to use. You can use to see all of your available models, or use a standard model like .

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.CompiledPrompt
member.summary: This is only used for serializing the request into JSON, do not use it directly.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.MultiplePrompts
member.summary: If you are requesting more than one prompt, specify them as an array of strings.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.Prompt
member.summary: For convenience, if you are only requesting a single prompt, set it here

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.Suffix
member.summary: The suffix that comes after a completion of inserted text. Defaults to null.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.MaxTokens
member.summary: How many tokens to complete to. Can return fewer if a stop sequence is hit. Defaults to 16.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.Temperature
member.summary: What sampling temperature to use. Higher values means the model will take more risks. Try 0.9 for more creative applications, and 0 (argmax sampling) for ones with a well-defined answer. It is generally recommend to use this or but not both.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.TopP
member.summary: An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered. It is generally recommend to use this or but not both.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.PresencePenalty
member.summary: The scale of the penalty applied if a token is already present at all. Should generally be between 0 and 1, although negative numbers are allowed to encourage token reuse. Defaults to 0.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.FrequencyPenalty
member.summary: The scale of the penalty for how often a token is used. Should generally be between 0 and 1, although negative numbers are allowed to encourage token reuse. Defaults to 0.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.NumChoicesPerPrompt
member.summary: How many different choices to request for each prompt. Defaults to 1.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.Stream
member.summary: Specifies where the results should stream and be returned at one time. Do not set this yourself, use the appropriate methods on instead.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.Logprobs
member.summary: Include the log probabilities on the logprobs most likely tokens, which can be found in -> . So for example, if logprobs is 5, the API will return a list of the 5 most likely tokens. If logprobs is supplied, the API will always return the logprob of the sampled token, so there may be up to logprobs+1 elements in the response. The maximum value for logprobs is 5.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.Echo
member.summary: Echo back the prompt in addition to the completion. Defaults to false.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.CompiledStop
member.summary: This is only used for serializing the request into JSON, do not use it directly.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.MultipleStopSequences
member.summary: One or more sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.StopSequence
member.summary: The stop sequence where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence. For convenience, if you are only requesting a single stop sequence, set it here

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Completions.CompletionRequest.BestOf
member.summary: Generates best_of completions server-side and returns the "best" (the one with the highest log probability per token). Results cannot be streamed. When used with n, best_of controls the number of candidate completions and n specifies how many to return best_of must be greater than n. Note: Because this parameter generates many completions, it can quickly consume your token quota.Use carefully and ensure that you have reasonable settings for max_tokens and stop.

member.summary: Ask the API to complete the prompt(s) using the specified parameters. Any non-specified parameters will fall back to default values specified in if present. If you are not using C# 8 supporting async enumerables or if you are using the .NET Framework, you may need to use instead.
member.param: The prompt to generate from
The model to use. You can use to see all of your available models, or use a standard model like .
How many tokens to complete to. Can return fewer if a stop sequence is hit.

What sampling temperature to use. Higher values means the model will take more risks. Try 0.9 for more creative applications, and 0 (argmax sampling) for ones with a well-defined answer. It is generally recommend to use this or but not both.

An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered. It is generally recommend to use this or but not both.
How many different choices to request for each prompt.
The scale of the penalty applied if a token is already present at all. Should generally be between 0 and 1, although negative numbers are allowed to encourage token reuse.
The scale of the penalty for how often a token is used. Should generally be between 0 and 1, although negative numbers are allowed to encourage token reuse.

Include the log probabilities on the logprobs most likely tokens, which can be found in -> . So for example, if logprobs is 10, the API will return a list of the 10 most likely tokens. If logprobs is supplied, the API will always return the logprob of the sampled token, so there may be up to logprobs+1 elements in the response.
Echo back the prompt in addition to the completion.
One or more sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.
member.returns: An async enumerable with each of the results as they come in. See the C# docs for more details on how to consume an async enumerable.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.IOpenAIAPI.Completions
member.summary: Text generation is the core function of the API. You give the API a prompt, and it generates a completion. The way you program the API to do a task is by simply describing the task in plain english or providing a few written examples. This simple approach works for a wide range of use cases, including summarization, translation, grammar correction, question answering, chatbots, composing emails, and much more (see the prompt library for inspiration).

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.GPT4
member.summary: More capable than any GPT-3.5 model, able to do more complex tasks, and optimized for chat. Will be updated with the latest model iteration.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.GPT4_32k_Context
member.summary: Same capabilities as the base gpt-4 model but with 4x the context length. Will be updated with the latest model iteration.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.GPT4_Vision
member.summary: Ability to understand images, in addition to all other GPT-4 Turbo capabilities. Returns a maximum of 4,096 output tokens. This is a preview model version and not suited yet for production traffic.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.GPT4_Turbo
member.summary: The latest GPT-4 model with improved instruction following, JSON mode, reproducible outputs, parallel function calling, and more. Returns a maximum of 4,096 output tokens. This preview model is not yet suited for production traffic.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.ChatGPTTurbo
member.summary: Most capable GPT-3.5 model and optimized for chat at 1/10th the cost of text-davinci-003. Will be updated with the latest model iteration.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.ChatGPTTurbo_16k
member.summary: The latest GPT-3.5 Turbo model with 16k context window, improved instruction following, JSON mode, reproducible outputs, parallel function calling, and more. Returns a maximum of 4,096 output tokens.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.ChatGPTTurboInstruct
member.summary: Similar capabilities as text-davinci-003 but compatible with legacy Completions endpoint and not Chat Completions.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.Babbage
member.summary: Replacement for the GPT-3 ada and babbage base models. GPT base models can understand and generate natural language or code but are not trained with instruction following. These models are made to be replacements for our original GPT-3 base models and use the legacy Completions API. Most customers should use GPT-3.5 or GPT-4.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.Davinci
member.summary: Replacement for the GPT-3 curie and davinci base model. GPT base models can understand and generate natural language or code but are not trained with instruction following. These models are made to be replacements for our original GPT-3 base models and use the legacy Completions API. Most customers should use GPT-3.5 or GPT-4.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.AdaText
member.summary: Capable of very simple tasks, usually the fastest model in the GPT-3 series, and lowest cost

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.BabbageText
member.summary: Capable of straightforward tasks, very fast, and lower cost.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.CurieText
member.summary: Very capable, but faster and lower cost than Davinci.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.DavinciText
member.summary: Will be deprecated by OpenAI on Jan 4th 2024. Use ("davinci-002") instead.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.CushmanCode
member.summary: Almost as capable as Davinci Codex, but slightly faster. This speed advantage may make it preferable for real-time applications.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.DavinciCode
member.summary: Will be deprecated by OpenAI on Jan 4th 2024.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.AdaTextEmbedding
member.summary: OpenAI offers one second-generation embedding model for use with the embeddings API endpoint.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.TextModerationStable
member.summary: Stable text moderation model that may provide lower accuracy compared to TextModerationLatest. OpenAI states they will provide advanced notice before updating this model.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.TextModerationLatest
member.summary: The latest text moderation model. This model will be automatically upgraded over time.

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.Models.Model.DALLE2

member.name: P:OpenAI_API.OpenAIAPI.Completions
member.summary: Text generation is the core function of the API. You give the API a prompt, and it generates a completion. The way you program the API to do a task is by simply describing the task in plain english or providing a few written examples. This simple approach works for a wide range of use cases, including summarization, translation, grammar correction, question answering, chatbots, composing emails, and much more (see the prompt library for inspiration).
